parent:hippo signaling pathway: Organ Size and Tissue Homeostasis Signaling

siblings:dna repair.name: Mismatch Repair
siblings:dna repair.description: Corrects mispaired bases and small insertion/deletion loops that escape proofreading during DNA replication.

siblings:dna repair.name: Homologous Recombination
siblings:dna repair.description: A high-fidelity repair mechanism for double-strand breaks that utilizes a homologous DNA template.

siblings:dna repair.name: Non-Homologous End Joining
siblings:dna repair.description: A pathway that repairs double-strand breaks by directly ligating the broken ends without the need for a homologous template.

siblings:dna repair.name: Direct Reversal
siblings:dna repair.description: A simple repair process that chemically reverses specific types of DNA damage, such as alkylation, without excision of bases.

siblings:dna repair.name: Interstrand Crosslink Repair
siblings:dna repair.description: A specialized pathway, often involving the Fanconi Anemia proteins, to resolve covalent links between the two strands of the DNA helix.

siblings:dna repair.name: Translesion Synthesis
siblings:dna repair.description: A damage tolerance mechanism that employs specialized DNA polymerases to bypass lesions during replication.

siblings:dna damage response.name: DNA Damage Sensing
siblings:dna damage response.description: The initial detection of DNA lesions by sensor proteins that initiate the signaling cascade.

siblings:dna damage response.name: Cell Cycle Checkpoint Activation
siblings:dna damage response.description: The temporary arrest of the cell cycle to allow time for repair before DNA replication or mitosis.

siblings:dna damage response.name: Apoptosis Induction
siblings:dna damage response.description: The activation of programmed cell death pathways when DNA damage is irreparable.

siblings:dna damage response.name: Cellular Senescence
siblings:dna damage response.description: A state of permanent cell cycle arrest triggered by persistent or unrepairable DNA damage.

siblings:dna damage response.name: Transcriptional Response
siblings:dna damage response.description: The modulation of gene expression to upregulate repair factors and stress-response proteins.

siblings:dna damage response.name: Chromatin Remodeling
siblings:dna damage response.description: The structural modification of chromatin to facilitate access of repair machinery to damaged DNA sites.

siblings:pi3k/akt signaling.name: mTOR Signaling
siblings:pi3k/akt signaling.description: A central regulator of cell growth and protein synthesis activated by Akt-mediated inhibition of TSC2.

siblings:pi3k/akt signaling.name: GSK3 Signaling
siblings:pi3k/akt signaling.description: Regulates glycogen synthesis and cell cycle progression through Akt-mediated phosphorylation and inhibition of Glycogen Synthase Kinase 3.

siblings:pi3k/akt signaling.name: Bad/Bcl-2 Mediated Apoptosis
siblings:pi3k/akt signaling.description: Promotes cell survival by Akt-mediated phosphorylation of the pro-apoptotic protein Bad, preventing its interaction with Bcl-xL.

siblings:pi3k/akt signaling.name: MDM2/p53 Signaling
siblings:pi3k/akt signaling.description: Regulates DNA damage responses and apoptosis via Akt-mediated phosphorylation of MDM2, which promotes p53 degradation.

siblings:pi3k/akt signaling.name: NF-kappaB Signaling
siblings:pi3k/akt signaling.description: Enhances cell survival and inflammatory responses through Akt-mediated activation of the IKK complex.

siblings:pi3k/akt signaling.name: p21/p27 Cell Cycle Regulation
siblings:pi3k/akt signaling.description: Controls cell cycle entry by Akt-mediated phosphorylation and cytoplasmic sequestration of cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitors.

siblings:pi3k/akt signaling.name: AS160/GLUT4 Translocation
siblings:pi3k/akt signaling.description: Regulates glucose uptake in muscle and adipose tissue through Akt-mediated phosphorylation of AS160.

siblings:growth factor and mitogenic sig.name: Cell Survival and Anti-apoptotic Signaling
siblings:growth factor and mitogenic sig.description: Pathways, such as PI3K/Akt, that inhibit programmed cell death to maintain cell viability in response to growth factors.

siblings:growth factor and mitogenic sig.name: Cell Differentiation Signaling
siblings:growth factor and mitogenic sig.description: Signaling cascades that direct unspecialized cells to develop into specific functional cell types.

siblings:growth factor and mitogenic sig.name: Cell Migration and Chemotaxis Signaling
siblings:growth factor and mitogenic sig.description: Processes that regulate the movement of cells toward growth factor gradients through cytoskeletal remodeling.

siblings:growth factor and mitogenic sig.name: Angiogenic Signaling
siblings:growth factor and mitogenic sig.description: Specific mitogenic signaling, often via VEGF, that triggers the growth of new blood vessels from existing ones.

siblings:growth factor and mitogenic sig.name: Metabolic Regulation and Nutrient Uptake
siblings:growth factor and mitogenic sig.description: Signaling that coordinates cellular metabolism and glucose transport to support the energetic demands of growth.

siblings:growth factor and mitogenic sig.name: Cytoskeletal Reorganization and Morphogenesis
siblings:growth factor and mitogenic sig.description: Pathways that alter cell shape and structural integrity in response to extracellular mitogenic stimuli.

siblings:protein misfolding.name: Chaperone-mediated Refolding
siblings:protein misfolding.description: The process by which molecular chaperones bind to misfolded proteins to facilitate their restoration to a native functional state.

siblings:protein misfolding.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum-Associated Degradation (ERAD)
siblings:protein misfolding.description: A pathway that identifies misfolded proteins in the ER and targets them for retrotranslocation to the cytosol for proteasomal degradation.

siblings:protein misfolding.name: Unfolded Protein Response (UPR)
siblings:protein misfolding.description: A cellular stress response related to the endoplasmic reticulum that halts protein translation and activates signaling to increase folding capacity.

siblings:protein misfolding.name: Ubiquitin-Proteasome System (UPS) Degradation
siblings:protein misfolding.description: The primary mechanism for the targeted destruction of misfolded or damaged proteins via polyubiquitination and the 26S proteasome.

siblings:protein misfolding.name: Autophagy-Lysosomal Degradation
siblings:protein misfolding.description: A pathway where misfolded proteins or damaged organelles are sequestered into autophagosomes and delivered to lysosomes for enzymatic breakdown.

siblings:protein misfolding.name: Prion-like Conformational Conversion
siblings:protein misfolding.description: The process where a misfolded protein template induces native proteins to adopt the same abnormal, self-propagating conformation.

siblings:protein misfolding.name: Functional Inactivation
siblings:protein misfolding.description: The immediate loss of biological activity resulting from the failure of a protein to achieve or maintain its correct three-dimensional structure.

siblings:rna metabolism.name: RNA Processing
siblings:rna metabolism.description: The series of enzymatic modifications to primary transcripts, including 5' capping, splicing, and 3' polyadenylation.

siblings:rna metabolism.name: RNA Decay
siblings:rna metabolism.description: The regulated degradation of RNA molecules by ribonucleases to control transcript abundance and eliminate faulty RNAs.

siblings:rna metabolism.name: RNA Transport
siblings:rna metabolism.description: The active movement of RNA molecules between cellular compartments, such as nuclear export to the cytoplasm.

siblings:rna metabolism.name: RNA Modification
siblings:rna metabolism.description: The post-transcriptional chemical alteration of RNA bases, including m6A methylation and pseudouridylation.

siblings:rna metabolism.name: RNA Surveillance
siblings:rna metabolism.description: Quality control pathways, such as nonsense-mediated decay, that detect and degrade aberrant mRNA transcripts.

siblings:rna metabolism.name: RNA Localization
siblings:rna metabolism.description: The targeted transport and anchoring of RNA molecules to specific subcellular regions or organelles.

siblings:apoptosis signaling.name: Extrinsic (Death Receptor) Pathway
siblings:apoptosis signaling.description: Initiated by the binding of extracellular ligands to transmembrane death receptors such as FAS, TNFR1, or DR4/5.

siblings:apoptosis signaling.name: Intrinsic (Mitochondrial) Pathway
siblings:apoptosis signaling.description: Triggered by intracellular stress signals that lead to mitochondrial outer membrane permeabilization and the release of cytochrome c.

siblings:apoptosis signaling.name: Caspase Cascade
siblings:apoptosis signaling.description: The central execution phase of apoptosis involving the sequential activation of initiator and executioner proteases.

siblings:apoptosis signaling.name: Perforin/Granzyme Pathway
siblings:apoptosis signaling.description: A specialized apoptotic route mediated by cytotoxic T lymphocytes and natural killer cells using pore-forming proteins and serine proteases.

siblings:apoptosis signaling.name: TRAIL Signaling Pathway
siblings:apoptosis signaling.description: A subset of the extrinsic pathway specifically mediated by the TNF-related apoptosis-inducing ligand.

siblings:apoptosis signaling.name: Bcl-2 Family Regulation
siblings:apoptosis signaling.description: The regulatory network of pro-apoptotic and anti-apoptotic proteins that govern the integrity of the mitochondrial membrane.

siblings:apoptosis signaling.name: IAP (Inhibitor of Apoptosis) Signaling
siblings:apoptosis signaling.description: A regulatory mechanism where IAP proteins bind to and neutralize active caspases to modulate the apoptotic threshold.

siblings:growth and proliferation signal.name: PI3K/Akt/mTOR Signaling
siblings:growth and proliferation signal.description: A central regulator of cell growth, protein synthesis, and metabolism in response to nutrients and growth factors.

siblings:growth and proliferation signal.name: MAPK/ERK Signaling
siblings:growth and proliferation signal.description: A key pathway that communicates signals from surface receptors to the nucleus to regulate cell cycle progression and proliferation.

siblings:growth and proliferation signal.name: Wnt Signaling
siblings:growth and proliferation signal.description: Regulates cell fate determination, proliferation, and tissue patterning during embryonic development and adult homeostasis.

siblings:growth and proliferation signal.name: Hedgehog Signaling
siblings:growth and proliferation signal.description: A critical pathway for embryonic development and tissue regeneration that controls cell growth and differentiation.

siblings:growth and proliferation signal.name: TGF-beta Signaling
siblings:growth and proliferation signal.description: Regulates a wide range of biological processes including cell growth, differentiation, and development through SMAD proteins.

siblings:growth and proliferation signal.name: JAK/STAT Signaling
siblings:growth and proliferation signal.description: Transmits signals from extracellular chemical signals to the nucleus, primarily regulating cell growth, survival, and immune response.

siblings:growth and proliferation signal.name: Notch Signaling
siblings:growth and proliferation signal.description: A highly conserved cell-to-cell signaling mechanism that governs cell-fate decisions and regulates proliferation in various tissues.

siblings:protein quality control.name: Protein Folding and Refolding
siblings:protein quality control.description: The process by which molecular chaperones assist nascent or misfolded polypeptides in achieving their native functional conformation.

siblings:protein quality control.name: Ubiquitin-Proteasome System (UPS)
siblings:protein quality control.description: A major pathway for the targeted degradation of short-lived, damaged, or misfolded proteins via polyubiquitination and the 26S proteasome.

siblings:protein quality control.name: Autophagy-Lysosomal Pathway
siblings:protein quality control.description: A degradation mechanism that targets large protein aggregates and damaged organelles for breakdown within lysosomes.

siblings:protein quality control.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum-Associated Degradation (ERAD)
siblings:protein quality control.description: A quality control mechanism that identifies misfolded proteins in the ER and retro-translocates them to the cytosol for proteasomal degradation.

siblings:protein quality control.name: Unfolded Protein Response (UPR)
siblings:protein quality control.description: A cellular stress response that senses misfolded proteins in the ER and activates signaling to restore proteostasis or induce apoptosis.

siblings:protein quality control.name: Protein Disaggregation
siblings:protein quality control.description: The active process of solubilizing and refolding protein aggregates, typically mediated by specialized chaperone systems like Hsp104/ClpB or Hsp70.

siblings:protein quality control.name: Mitochondria-associated Degradation (MAD)
siblings:protein quality control.description: A surveillance pathway responsible for the identification and clearance of misfolded proteins within the mitochondria or on the outer mitochondrial membrane.

siblings:regulation of gene expression.name: Transcriptional Regulation
siblings:regulation of gene expression.description: The control of the rate of gene transcription, typically by the binding of transcription factors to specific DNA sequences.

siblings:regulation of gene expression.name: Epigenetic Regulation
siblings:regulation of gene expression.description: Heritable changes in gene expression that do not involve alterations to the underlying DNA sequence, such as DNA methylation and histone modification.

siblings:regulation of gene expression.name: Translational Regulation
siblings:regulation of gene expression.description: The control of the levels of protein synthesized from its mRNA, often through the modulation of translation initiation factors.

siblings:regulation of gene expression.name: Post-translational Regulation
siblings:regulation of gene expression.description: The control of protein activity, stability, and localization through covalent modifications or proteolytic cleavage after protein synthesis.

siblings:regulation of gene expression.name: Chromatin Remodeling
siblings:regulation of gene expression.description: The rearrangement of chromatin structure to allow transcription factors and other DNA-binding proteins to access the genome.

siblings:regulation of gene expression.name: mRNA Transport and Localization
siblings:regulation of gene expression.description: The regulated movement of mRNA from the nucleus to specific regions of the cytoplasm to control where proteins are produced.

siblings:proteotoxic stress response.name: Unfolded Protein Response (ER)
siblings:proteotoxic stress response.description: A signaling pathway activated by the accumulation of misfolded proteins in the endoplasmic reticulum lumen to restore proteostasis.

siblings:proteotoxic stress response.name: Mitochondrial Unfolded Protein Response (UPRmt)
siblings:proteotoxic stress response.description: A stress response that promotes mitochondrial proteostasis by upregulating nuclear-encoded mitochondrial chaperones and proteases.

siblings:proteotoxic stress response.name: Ubiquitin-Proteasome System (UPS)
siblings:proteotoxic stress response.description: The primary cellular mechanism for the targeted degradation of misfolded or damaged proteins via polyubiquitination.

siblings:proteotoxic stress response.name: Autophagy-Lysosome Pathway
siblings:proteotoxic stress response.description: A catabolic process that degrades large protein aggregates and damaged organelles through sequestration into autophagosomes.

siblings:proteotoxic stress response.name: Integrated Stress Response (ISR)
siblings:proteotoxic stress response.description: A signaling network that reduces general protein synthesis while selectively increasing the translation of genes involved in stress recovery.

siblings:proteotoxic stress response.name: Aggresome Formation
siblings:proteotoxic stress response.description: A cytoprotective mechanism that sequesters toxic protein aggregates at the microtubule-organizing center for eventual clearance.

siblings:proteostasis.name: Protein Folding and Chaperone-mediated Refolding
siblings:proteostasis.description: The process by which molecular chaperones assist nascent polypeptides in reaching their native functional conformation.

siblings:proteostasis.name: Ubiquitin-Proteasome System (UPS)
siblings:proteostasis.description: A major pathway for the targeted degradation of short-lived, damaged, or misfolded proteins via ubiquitination.

siblings:proteostasis.name: Autophagy-Lysosome Pathway
siblings:proteostasis.description: A bulk degradation mechanism that delivers cytoplasmic components, including large protein aggregates, to lysosomes.

siblings:proteostasis.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum-Associated Degradation (ERAD)
siblings:proteostasis.description: A quality control process that targets misfolded proteins in the ER for retrotranslocation and proteasomal degradation.

siblings:proteostasis.name: Unfolded Protein Response (UPR)
siblings:proteostasis.description: A cellular stress response related to the ER that halts translation and increases chaperone production to restore homeostasis.

siblings:proteostasis.name: Protein Synthesis and Translation Control
siblings:proteostasis.description: Regulation of the rate and accuracy of mRNA translation to ensure the production of functional proteins.

siblings:response to reactive oxygen spe.name: Cellular response to hydrogen peroxide
siblings:response to reactive oxygen spe.description: A specific set of cellular changes and signaling events triggered by the presence of hydrogen peroxide.

siblings:response to reactive oxygen spe.name: Cellular response to superoxide
siblings:response to reactive oxygen spe.description: Biological processes and molecular adaptations initiated in response to superoxide anion radicals.

siblings:response to reactive oxygen spe.name: Cellular response to singlet oxygen
siblings:response to reactive oxygen spe.description: The series of molecular events and protective mechanisms activated by exposure to singlet oxygen.

siblings:response to reactive oxygen spe.name: Cellular response to hydroxyl radical
siblings:response to reactive oxygen spe.description: Specific cellular reactions and repair mechanisms induced by the highly reactive hydroxyl radical.

siblings:response to reactive oxygen spe.name: Detection of reactive oxygen species
siblings:response to reactive oxygen spe.description: The biochemical pathways and sensory mechanisms used by a cell to identify the presence and concentration of ROS.

siblings:response to reactive oxygen spe.name: Regulation of response to reactive oxygen species
siblings:response to reactive oxygen spe.description: Processes that modulate the frequency, rate, or extent of the cellular response to reactive oxygen species.

siblings:response to oxidative stress.name: Response to Hydrogen Peroxide
siblings:response to oxidative stress.description: Any process that results in a change in state or activity of a cell or an organism as a result of a hydrogen peroxide stimulus.

siblings:response to oxidative stress.name: Response to Superoxide
siblings:response to oxidative stress.description: Any process that results in a change in state or activity of a cell or an organism as a result of a superoxide stimulus.

siblings:response to oxidative stress.name: Response to Singlet Oxygen
siblings:response to oxidative stress.description: Any process that results in a change in state or activity of a cell or an organism as a result of a singlet oxygen stimulus.

siblings:response to oxidative stress.name: Response to Hydroxyl Radical
siblings:response to oxidative stress.description: Any process that results in a change in state or activity of a cell or an organism as a result of a hydroxyl radical stimulus.

siblings:response to oxidative stress.name: Cellular Response to Oxidative Stress
siblings:response to oxidative stress.description: Any process that results in a change in state or activity of a cell (in terms of movement, secretion, enzyme production, etc.) as a result of oxidative stress.

siblings:response to oxidative stress.name: Regulation of Response to Oxidative Stress
siblings:response to oxidative stress.description: Any process that modulates the frequency, rate, or extent of the response to oxidative stress.

siblings:response to oxidative stress.name: Response to Hydroperoxide
siblings:response to oxidative stress.description: Any process that results in a change in state or activity of a cell or an organism as a result of a hydroperoxide stimulus.

siblings:autophagy.name: Microautophagy
siblings:autophagy.description: The direct engulfment of cytoplasmic material by the lysosomal or vacuolar membrane through invagination or protrusion.

siblings:autophagy.name: Chaperone-mediated autophagy
siblings:autophagy.description: A selective degradation pathway where proteins with a KFERQ-like motif are recognized by Hsc70 and translocated across the lysosomal membrane via LAMP2A.

siblings:autophagy.name: Mitophagy
siblings:autophagy.description: The selective autophagic degradation of damaged or redundant mitochondria to maintain cellular health.

siblings:autophagy.name: Pexophagy
siblings:autophagy.description: The selective degradation of peroxisomes via the autophagic machinery, often in response to environmental changes.

siblings:autophagy.name: Xenophagy
siblings:autophagy.description: The autophagic process of targeting and eliminating intracellular pathogens, such as bacteria and viruses.

siblings:autophagy.name: Lipophagy
siblings:autophagy.description: The selective autophagic degradation of lipid droplets into free fatty acids to regulate energy metabolism.

siblings:autophagy.name: Nucleophagy
siblings:autophagy.description: The selective degradation of nuclear components, including parts of the nuclear envelope and nucleoplasm, to maintain genomic integrity.

siblings:chromatin organization.name: Histone Modification
siblings:chromatin organization.description: The covalent post-translational modification of histone proteins, such as acetylation, methylation, or phosphorylation, to regulate chromatin structure.

siblings:chromatin organization.name: Nucleosome Assembly
siblings:chromatin organization.description: The process of organizing DNA and histone octamers into nucleosome units, the fundamental building blocks of chromatin.

siblings:chromatin organization.name: Nucleosome Disassembly
siblings:chromatin organization.description: The removal or displacement of histone octamers from DNA to allow access for transcription, replication, or repair machinery.

siblings:chromatin organization.name: Histone Exchange
siblings:chromatin organization.description: The replacement of canonical histones within a nucleosome with specific histone variants to alter chromatin properties.

siblings:chromatin organization.name: DNA Methylation
siblings:chromatin organization.description: The addition of methyl groups to DNA, typically at CpG sites, which contributes to the formation of condensed, inactive chromatin.

siblings:chromatin organization.name: Chromatin Silencing
siblings:chromatin organization.description: The formation of transcriptionally repressed heterochromatin regions through the recruitment of specific silencing complexes.

siblings:second messenger signaling.name: cAMP Signaling Pathway
siblings:second messenger signaling.description: Utilizes cyclic adenosine monophosphate to activate protein kinase A (PKA) and regulate metabolic processes.

siblings:second messenger signaling.name: cGMP Signaling Pathway
siblings:second messenger signaling.description: Uses cyclic guanosine monophosphate to activate protein kinase G (PKG), often mediating vasodilation and phototransduction.

siblings:second messenger signaling.name: Phosphatidylinositol Signaling Pathway
siblings:second messenger signaling.description: Involves the hydrolysis of membrane phospholipids into inositol triphosphate (IP3) and diacylglycerol (DAG).

siblings:second messenger signaling.name: Nitric Oxide Signaling Pathway
siblings:second messenger signaling.description: Employs the gaseous molecule nitric oxide to activate soluble guanylyl cyclase and modulate vascular tone.

siblings:second messenger signaling.name: Arachidonic Acid Signaling Pathway
siblings:second messenger signaling.description: Involves the release of arachidonic acid from the plasma membrane to produce eicosanoid messengers like prostaglandins.

siblings:second messenger signaling.name: Sphingolipid Signaling Pathway
siblings:second messenger signaling.description: Uses bioactive lipids such as ceramide and sphingosine-1-phosphate to regulate cell survival and apoptosis.

siblings:protein degradation.name: Autophagy-Lysosome Pathway
siblings:protein degradation.description: A major intracellular degradation system where cytoplasmic components are sequestered into autophagosomes and delivered to lysosomes for digestion.

siblings:protein degradation.name: Chaperone-Mediated Autophagy
siblings:protein degradation.description: A selective degradation pathway where proteins with a specific motif are recognized by chaperones and translocated directly across the lysosomal membrane.

siblings:protein degradation.name: Calpain System
siblings:protein degradation.description: A family of calcium-dependent, non-lysosomal cysteine proteases that mediate limited proteolysis of substrates involved in cell signaling and cytoskeleton structure.

siblings:protein degradation.name: Caspase System
siblings:protein degradation.description: A family of protease enzymes that play essential roles in programmed cell death (apoptosis) and inflammatory signaling through targeted protein cleavage.

siblings:protein degradation.name: Endosomal-Lysosomal Pathway
siblings:protein degradation.description: The degradation route for extracellular and plasma membrane proteins internalized via endocytosis and sorted through endosomes to lysosomes.

siblings:protein degradation.name: Matrix Metalloproteinases
siblings:protein degradation.description: Zinc-dependent enzymes responsible for the degradation of extracellular matrix proteins, crucial for tissue remodeling and cell migration.

siblings:protein degradation.name: Microautophagy
siblings:protein degradation.description: A process where the lysosomal or vacuolar membrane directly engulfs cytoplasmic material through invagination or protrusion for degradation.

siblings:intracellular signal transducti.name: Protein Phosphorylation Cascades
siblings:intracellular signal transducti.description: The transmission of signals through the sequential addition of phosphate groups to proteins by kinases.

siblings:intracellular signal transducti.name: Small GTPase Mediated Transduction
siblings:intracellular signal transducti.description: Signaling involving molecular switches like Ras and Rho that cycle between active GTP-bound and inactive GDP-bound states.

siblings:intracellular signal transducti.name: Nuclear Receptor Signaling
siblings:intracellular signal transducti.description: A direct transduction pathway where lipophilic ligands bind to intracellular receptors that function as transcription factors.

siblings:intracellular signal transducti.name: Proteolytic Signaling
siblings:intracellular signal transducti.description: Signal transduction pathways, such as Notch or NF-kappaB, that rely on the regulated cleavage of proteins to activate downstream effects.

siblings:intracellular signal transducti.name: Ion Channel-Mediated Signaling
siblings:intracellular signal transducti.description: The transduction of signals via the flux of ions across membranes, altering cellular membrane potential or internal ion concentrations.

siblings:intracellular signal transducti.name: Scaffold-Mediated Signaling
siblings:intracellular signal transducti.description: The organization of signaling components into physical complexes by scaffolding proteins to enhance the specificity and efficiency of the signal.

siblings:signal transduction.name: MAPK Signaling Pathway
siblings:signal transduction.description: A highly conserved pathway that relays extracellular signals to the nucleus to regulate cell growth, differentiation, and stress responses.

siblings:signal transduction.name: Wnt Signaling Pathway
siblings:signal transduction.description: A group of signal transduction pathways that regulate cell fate determination, polarity, and embryonic development.

siblings:signal transduction.name: Notch Signaling Pathway
siblings:signal transduction.description: A conserved cell-to-cell communication mechanism that governs cell differentiation and pattern formation.

siblings:signal transduction.name: TGF-beta Signaling Pathway
siblings:signal transduction.description: Regulates diverse cellular processes including cell growth, apoptosis, and development through Smad-dependent and independent mechanisms.

siblings:signal transduction.name: JAK-STAT Signaling Pathway
siblings:signal transduction.description: Transmits information from extracellular chemical signals, such as cytokines and growth factors, directly to gene promoters in the nucleus.

siblings:signal transduction.name: PI3K-Akt Signaling Pathway
siblings:signal transduction.description: An intracellular pathway that promotes metabolism, proliferation, and cell survival in response to extracellular signals.

siblings:signal transduction.name: GPCR Signaling
siblings:signal transduction.description: The largest family of cell surface receptors that convert external stimuli into intracellular responses via G-proteins.

siblings:cellular response to stress.name: Response to DNA Damage Stimulus
siblings:cellular response to stress.description: A set of molecular processes that detect and repair lesions in the cellular genome caused by genotoxic agents.

siblings:cellular response to stress.name: Response to Heat
siblings:cellular response to stress.description: The cellular changes, including the induction of heat shock proteins, resulting from an increase in temperature.

siblings:cellular response to stress.name: Response to Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress
siblings:cellular response to stress.description: Activation of the unfolded protein response (UPR) to restore protein folding homeostasis within the ER lumen.

siblings:cellular response to stress.name: Response to Hypoxia
siblings:cellular response to stress.description: The cellular adaptive response to low oxygen tension, typically mediated by hypoxia-inducible factors (HIFs).

siblings:cellular response to stress.name: Response to Osmotic Stress
siblings:cellular response to stress.description: The physiological and molecular changes triggered by a change in the solute concentration around a cell.

siblings:cellular response to stress.name: Response to Nutrient Levels
siblings:cellular response to stress.description: A cellular response to fluctuations in the availability of essential nutrients such as glucose, amino acids, or lipids.

siblings:cellular response to stress.name: Response to Cold
siblings:cellular response to stress.description: The cellular processes and gene expression changes triggered by a decrease in temperature to maintain membrane fluidity and function.

siblings:gene expression.name: Transcription
siblings:gene expression.description: The process by which genetic information encoded in DNA is copied into a complementary RNA sequence by RNA polymerase.

siblings:gene expression.name: Translation
siblings:gene expression.description: The synthesis of a polypeptide chain from an mRNA template by ribosomes and tRNA molecules.

siblings:gene expression.name: Epigenetic regulation of gene expression
siblings:gene expression.description: The modification of gene activity without altering the DNA sequence, often through DNA methylation or histone modification.

siblings:gene expression.name: Chromatin organization
siblings:gene expression.description: The structural arrangement of DNA and associated proteins that controls the accessibility of genes for transcription.

siblings:gene expression.name: Post-translational protein modification
siblings:gene expression.description: The enzymatic processing of polypeptide chains following translation to produce functional, mature protein products.

siblings:cellular response to stimuli.name: Cellular response to external stimuli
siblings:cellular response to stimuli.description: The process where a cell changes its state or activity as a result of an external signal such as a chemical or physical stimulus.

siblings:cellular response to stimuli.name: Cellular response to starvation
siblings:cellular response to stimuli.description: A series of metabolic and signaling adjustments, including autophagy, triggered by the deprivation of essential nutrients.

siblings:cellular response to stimuli.name: Cellular response to hypoxia
siblings:cellular response to stimuli.description: The molecular adaptations, primarily mediated by Hypoxia-Inducible Factors (HIFs), to low oxygen tension.

siblings:cellular response to stimuli.name: Cellular response to nutrient levels
siblings:cellular response to stimuli.description: Signaling pathways, such as the mTOR pathway, that sense and respond to the availability of amino acids, glucose, and lipids.

siblings:cellular response to stimuli.name: Cellular response to metal ions
siblings:cellular response to stimuli.description: Homeostatic and detoxification mechanisms activated in response to changes in the concentration of metal ions like zinc, copper, or iron.

siblings:cellular response to stimuli.name: Cellular response to radiation
siblings:cellular response to stimuli.description: The activation of DNA damage repair and cell cycle checkpoint pathways following exposure to ionizing or ultraviolet radiation.

siblings:cell fate and survival.name: Cell Cycle
siblings:cell fate and survival.description: The highly regulated series of events that lead to DNA replication and the division of a cell into two daughter cells.

siblings:cell fate and survival.name: Cell Proliferation
siblings:cell fate and survival.description: The process by which a cell grows and divides to produce two daughter cells, leading to an exponential increase in cell number.

siblings:cell fate and survival.name: Cell Differentiation
siblings:cell fate and survival.description: The process by which a less specialized cell becomes a more specialized cell type with distinct functions and structures.

siblings:cell fate and survival.name: Cell Senescence
siblings:cell fate and survival.description: A state of stable, irreversible cell cycle arrest that acts as a protective mechanism against the proliferation of damaged cells.

siblings:cell fate and survival.name: Autophagy
siblings:cell fate and survival.description: A self-degradative survival process that recycles cytoplasmic components via lysosomes to maintain cellular homeostasis during stress.

siblings:cell fate and survival.name: DNA Repair
siblings:cell fate and survival.description: A collection of processes by which a cell identifies and corrects damage to the DNA molecules that encode its genome, ensuring genomic stability.

siblings:epigenetic regulation.name: DNA Methylation
siblings:epigenetic regulation.description: The covalent addition of methyl groups to DNA, typically at CpG sites, which generally leads to gene silencing.

siblings:epigenetic regulation.name: Histone Modification
siblings:epigenetic regulation.description: Post-translational modifications to histone proteins, such as acetylation, methylation, and phosphorylation, that influence gene accessibility.

siblings:epigenetic regulation.name: Non-coding RNA-mediated Regulation
siblings:epigenetic regulation.description: The regulation of gene expression by functional RNA molecules like lncRNAs and miRNAs that do not code for proteins.

siblings:epigenetic regulation.name: Chromatin Remodeling
siblings:epigenetic regulation.description: The ATP-dependent alteration of nucleosome positioning or composition to facilitate or prevent access to genomic DNA.

siblings:epigenetic regulation.name: Genomic Imprinting
siblings:epigenetic regulation.description: An epigenetic process resulting in parent-of-origin-specific gene expression through differential methylation.

siblings:epigenetic regulation.name: X-chromosome Inactivation
siblings:epigenetic regulation.description: The transcriptional silencing of one of the two X chromosomes in female mammals to ensure balanced gene dosage.

siblings:protein folding.name: Co-translational protein folding
siblings:protein folding.description: The folding of a nascent polypeptide chain into its secondary and tertiary structures as it emerges from the ribosome.

siblings:protein folding.name: Post-translational protein folding
siblings:protein folding.description: The process where a fully synthesized polypeptide chain achieves its native conformation after release from the ribosome.

siblings:protein folding.name: Folding of actin and tubulin
siblings:protein folding.description: A specialized folding pathway mediated by the CCT/TRiC chaperonin complex specifically for cytoskeletal proteins.

siblings:protein folding.name: Protein folding in the endoplasmic reticulum
siblings:protein folding.description: The maturation and folding of secretory and membrane proteins within the specialized environment of the ER lumen.

siblings:protein folding.name: Disulfide bond formation
siblings:protein folding.description: The enzymatic creation of covalent linkages between cysteine residues that stabilize the tertiary and quaternary structure of proteins.

siblings:protein folding.name: Peptidyl-prolyl cis-trans isomerization
siblings:protein folding.description: The interconversion of proline peptide bond isomers, often a rate-limiting step in the protein folding process.

siblings:protein folding.name: Formation of quaternary structure
siblings:protein folding.description: The assembly of multiple independently folded polypeptide subunits into a functional multi-subunit protein complex.

siblings:regulation of transcription.name: Transcription Factor Binding
siblings:regulation of transcription.description: The recruitment and binding of sequence-specific proteins to promoters or enhancers to initiate or inhibit the transcription process.

siblings:regulation of transcription.name: Chromatin Remodeling
siblings:regulation of transcription.description: The ATP-dependent modification of chromatin architecture to facilitate or restrict access of transcriptional machinery to DNA.

siblings:regulation of transcription.name: RNA Polymerase II Recruitment and Initiation
siblings:regulation of transcription.description: The assembly of the pre-initiation complex and the start of RNA synthesis at the transcription start site.

siblings:regulation of transcription.name: Transcriptional Elongation Control
siblings:regulation of transcription.description: Regulation of the rate and processivity of RNA polymerase as it moves along the DNA template during RNA synthesis.

siblings:regulation of transcription.name: Enhancer-Promoter Looping
siblings:regulation of transcription.description: The physical interaction between distal regulatory elements and target gene promoters through DNA looping.

siblings:regulation of transcription.name: Transcriptional Termination
siblings:regulation of transcription.description: The signaling and enzymatic processes that cause RNA polymerase to release the DNA template and the nascent RNA transcript.

siblings:regulation of transcription.name: Co-regulator Recruitment
siblings:regulation of transcription.description: The association of co-activators and co-repressors with DNA-bound transcription factors to modulate gene expression levels.

siblings:cellular signaling.name: Signal Transduction
siblings:cellular signaling.description: The biochemical process by which a cell converts an extracellular signal into a specific intracellular response.

siblings:cellular signaling.name: Cell-Cell Communication
siblings:cellular signaling.description: The transmission of signals between cells via direct contact or secreted molecules to coordinate physiological activities.

siblings:cellular signaling.name: Growth and Differentiation
siblings:cellular signaling.description: Signaling pathways that regulate the increase in cell mass, proliferation, and the acquisition of specialized cell functions.

siblings:cellular signaling.name: Metabolic Signaling
siblings:cellular signaling.description: The integration of nutrient sensing and hormonal inputs to regulate cellular energy balance and metabolic flux.

siblings:cellular signaling.name: Stress Response
siblings:cellular signaling.description: Signaling cascades activated by internal or external stressors, such as oxidative stress or DNA damage, to maintain cellular integrity.

siblings:cellular signaling.name: Hormone Signaling
siblings:cellular signaling.description: Long-distance signaling involving the release of hormones into the circulatory system to regulate distant target organs.

siblings:excision repair.name: Base Excision Repair (BER)
siblings:excision repair.description: Identifies and removes small, non-helix-distorting base lesions such as those caused by oxidation, alkylation, or deamination.

siblings:excision repair.name: Mismatch Repair (MMR)
siblings:excision repair.description: Corrects mispaired bases and small insertion/deletion loops that escape proofreading during DNA replication.

siblings:excision repair.name: Ribonucleotide Excision Repair (RER)
siblings:excision repair.description: A specialized excision pathway that removes ribonucleotides mistakenly incorporated into DNA by DNA polymerases.

siblings:excision repair.name: Alternative Excision Repair (AER)
siblings:excision repair.description: Non-canonical pathways, such as those utilizing UV-damage endonucleases (UVDER), that serve as backups to standard NER or BER.

siblings:excision repair.name: Single-Strand Break Repair (SSBR)
siblings:excision repair.description: A pathway closely related to BER that specifically repairs breaks in the phosphodiester backbone of one DNA strand.

siblings:programmed cell death.name: Necroptosis
siblings:programmed cell death.description: A regulated form of necrotic cell death mediated by the RIPK1-RIPK3-MLKL signaling pathway.

siblings:programmed cell death.name: Pyroptosis
siblings:programmed cell death.description: A highly inflammatory form of programmed cell death typically triggered by inflammasome activation and gasdermin pore formation.

siblings:programmed cell death.name: Ferroptosis
siblings:programmed cell death.description: An iron-dependent form of regulated cell death characterized by the accumulation of lipid peroxides and oxidative membrane damage.

siblings:programmed cell death.name: Autophagy-dependent cell death
siblings:programmed cell death.description: A form of regulated cell death that mechanistically depends upon the autophagic machinery of the cell.

siblings:programmed cell death.name: Parthanatos
siblings:programmed cell death.description: A programmed cell death pathway initiated by the overactivation of PARP-1 and the subsequent translocation of AIF from mitochondria to the nucleus.

siblings:programmed cell death.name: NETosis
siblings:programmed cell death.description: A specialized form of programmed cell death in neutrophils involving the release of neutrophil extracellular traps composed of DNA and granular proteins.

siblings:genome maintenance.name: Global Genomic Repair
siblings:genome maintenance.description: A sub-pathway of nucleotide excision repair that scans the entire genome for bulky DNA lesions independently of transcription.

siblings:genome maintenance.name: Base Excision Repair
siblings:genome maintenance.description: A mechanism that repairs small, non-bulky DNA lesions such as oxidized, alkylated, or deaminated bases.

siblings:genome maintenance.name: Mismatch Repair
siblings:genome maintenance.description: A system for recognizing and repairing erroneous insertion, deletion, and mis-incorporation of bases that can arise during DNA replication.

siblings:genome maintenance.name: Homologous Recombination
siblings:genome maintenance.description: A high-fidelity mechanism for repairing double-strand breaks using a homologous DNA sequence as a template.

siblings:genome maintenance.name: Non-Homologous End Joining
siblings:genome maintenance.description: A pathway that repairs double-strand breaks by directly ligating the broken ends without the need for a homologous template.

siblings:genome maintenance.name: Fanconi Anemia Pathway
siblings:genome maintenance.description: A specialized DNA repair network dedicated to the recognition and removal of DNA interstrand crosslinks.

siblings:genome maintenance.name: Direct Reversal of Damage
siblings:genome maintenance.description: A simple repair mechanism that chemically reverses specific types of DNA damage, such as alkylation, without removing bases.

siblings:transcription.name: RNA Polymerase I Transcription
siblings:transcription.description: The process of synthesizing ribosomal RNA (rRNA) precursors from the rDNA locus.

siblings:transcription.name: RNA Polymerase II Transcription
siblings:transcription.description: The synthesis of messenger RNA (mRNA) and most small nuclear RNAs from protein-coding genes.

siblings:transcription.name: RNA Polymerase III Transcription
siblings:transcription.description: The synthesis of transfer RNA (tRNA), 5S rRNA, and other small stable RNAs.

siblings:transcription.name: Mitochondrial Transcription
siblings:transcription.description: The expression of genes encoded within the mitochondrial genome by mitochondria-specific machinery.

siblings:transcription.name: Transcription Initiation
siblings:transcription.description: The assembly of the pre-initiation complex and the first phosphodiester bond formation.

siblings:transcription.name: Transcription Elongation
siblings:transcription.description: The process of RNA strand growth as RNA polymerase moves along the DNA template.

siblings:transcription.name: Transcription Termination
siblings:transcription.description: The sequence-specific dissociation of the transcription complex and release of the RNA transcript.

siblings:protein folding and stability.name: Chaperone-mediated protein folding
siblings:protein folding and stability.description: The process by which molecular chaperones assist in the correct folding of nascent or denatured polypeptides.

siblings:protein folding and stability.name: Co-translational protein folding
siblings:protein folding and stability.description: Folding of a polypeptide chain that occurs simultaneously with its synthesis on the ribosome.

siblings:protein folding and stability.name: Post-translational protein folding
siblings:protein folding and stability.description: The folding of a protein into its functional three-dimensional structure after its synthesis is complete.

siblings:protein folding and stability.name: Oxidative protein folding
siblings:protein folding and stability.description: The formation of stabilizing disulfide bonds within a protein, typically occurring in the endoplasmic reticulum.

siblings:protein folding and stability.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum-Associated Degradation (ERAD)
siblings:protein folding and stability.description: A quality control pathway that targets misfolded proteins in the ER for ubiquitination and degradation by the proteasome.

siblings:protein folding and stability.name: Unfolded Protein Response (UPR)
siblings:protein folding and stability.description: A cellular stress response that acts to restore protein folding homeostasis in the endoplasmic reticulum.

siblings:protein folding and stability.name: Protein aggregation
siblings:protein folding and stability.description: The process by which misfolded proteins associate into stable, often insoluble, multi-protein complexes.

siblings:organ size and tissue homeostas.name: Wnt Signaling Pathway
siblings:organ size and tissue homeostas.description: Regulates cell proliferation, differentiation, and tissue architecture during development and homeostasis.

siblings:organ size and tissue homeostas.name: Notch Signaling Pathway
siblings:organ size and tissue homeostas.description: Controls cell fate decisions and maintains tissue homeostasis through direct cell-to-cell communication.

siblings:organ size and tissue homeostas.name: TGF-beta Signaling Pathway
siblings:organ size and tissue homeostas.description: Influences cell growth, apoptosis, and differentiation to regulate organ size and tissue remodeling.

siblings:organ size and tissue homeostas.name: Hedgehog Signaling Pathway
siblings:organ size and tissue homeostas.description: Essential for embryonic patterning and the maintenance of adult tissue stem cell populations.

siblings:organ size and tissue homeostas.name: PI3K/Akt/mTOR Signaling Pathway
siblings:organ size and tissue homeostas.description: Integrates nutrient and growth factor signals to regulate cell size, metabolism, and protein synthesis.

siblings:organ size and tissue homeostas.name: JAK/STAT Signaling Pathway
siblings:organ size and tissue homeostas.description: Mediates cellular responses to cytokines and growth factors involved in tissue regeneration and immune homeostasis.

siblings:organ size and tissue homeostas.name: MAPK/ERK Signaling Pathway
siblings:organ size and tissue homeostas.description: Transmits extracellular signals to the nucleus to regulate cell cycle progression and proliferation.

siblings:er quality control.name: Unfolded Protein Response (UPR)
siblings:er quality control.description: A signaling pathway that senses the accumulation of misfolded proteins and coordinates a cellular response to restore ER homeostasis.

siblings:er quality control.name: ER-phagy
siblings:er quality control.description: The selective autophagy of the endoplasmic reticulum used to degrade large protein aggregates or excess ER membrane that cannot be handled by ERAD.

siblings:er quality control.name: Calnexin/Calreticulin Cycle
siblings:er quality control.description: A specialized folding pathway for N-linked glycoproteins that uses lectin-like chaperones to ensure proper folding before ER exit.

siblings:er quality control.name: ER Retention
siblings:er quality control.description: The mechanism by which misfolded or incompletely assembled proteins are actively withheld from the secretory pathway by resident ER chaperones.

siblings:er quality control.name: ER-to-Lysosome Degradation (ERLD)
siblings:er quality control.description: A degradation route for misfolded proteins that bypasses the ubiquitin-proteasome system and delivers cargo directly to lysosomes.

siblings:er quality control.name: ER Export Control
siblings:er quality control.description: A quality control checkpoint at ER exit sites that ensures only correctly folded and assembled proteins are packaged into COPII vesicles.

siblings:growth factor signaling.name: MAPK/ERK Signaling
siblings:growth factor signaling.description: A protein kinase cascade (Ras-Raf-MEK-ERK) that transmits signals from surface receptors to the nucleus to regulate cell proliferation and differentiation.

siblings:growth factor signaling.name: JAK/STAT Signaling
siblings:growth factor signaling.description: A pathway activated by various growth factors and cytokines where Janus kinases phosphorylate STAT proteins to directly regulate gene transcription.

siblings:growth factor signaling.name: PLC/PKC Signaling
siblings:growth factor signaling.description: Involves the activation of Phospholipase C-gamma, leading to the generation of IP3 and DAG, which trigger calcium release and Protein Kinase C activation.

siblings:growth factor signaling.name: TGF-beta/Smad Signaling
siblings:growth factor signaling.description: A pathway where Transforming Growth Factor-beta ligands bind to receptors that phosphorylate Smad proteins to modulate growth and developmental genes.

siblings:growth factor signaling.name: Hippo Signaling
siblings:growth factor signaling.description: An evolutionarily conserved signaling cascade that regulates organ size by controlling cell proliferation, apoptosis, and stem cell self-renewal.

siblings:growth factor signaling.name: Wnt/beta-catenin Signaling
siblings:growth factor signaling.description: A signal transduction pathway that regulates cell fate and growth by controlling the stability and nuclear localization of beta-catenin.

siblings:secretory pathway quality contr.name: Golgi Quality Control
siblings:secretory pathway quality contr.description: Mechanisms that identify and divert misfolded proteins within the Golgi apparatus for degradation or retrieval to the ER.

siblings:secretory pathway quality contr.name: Plasma Membrane Quality Control
siblings:secretory pathway quality contr.description: Surveillance processes that monitor the conformational integrity of proteins at the cell surface, triggering endocytosis of damaged proteins.

siblings:secretory pathway quality contr.name: Endosomal Quality Control
siblings:secretory pathway quality contr.description: Sorting pathways within endosomes that distinguish between functional proteins for recycling and misfolded proteins for lysosomal degradation.

siblings:secretory pathway quality contr.name: Extracellular Quality Control
siblings:secretory pathway quality contr.description: The action of secreted chaperones and proteases that manage the folding and aggregation of proteins in the extracellular space.

siblings:secretory pathway quality contr.name: Lysosomal Quality Control
siblings:secretory pathway quality contr.description: The final degradation stage for misfolded secretory proteins that have been routed through the endocytic or biosynthetic pathways.

siblings:secretory pathway quality contr.name: Post-Golgi Quality Control
siblings:secretory pathway quality contr.description: A collective term for surveillance mechanisms acting on proteins after they have exited the Golgi but before reaching their final destination.

siblings:cell death.name: Necrotic Cell Death
siblings:cell death.description: A form of accidental cell death resulting from overwhelming external physical or chemical injury, characterized by cell swelling and plasma membrane rupture.

siblings:cell death.name: Autophagic Cell Death
siblings:cell death.description: A morphologically distinct form of cell death characterized by the large-scale accumulation of autophagic vacuoles in the cytoplasm.

siblings:cell death.name: Mitotic Catastrophe
siblings:cell death.description: A mechanism of cell death that occurs during or shortly after a dysfunctional mitosis, often triggered by DNA damage or spindle defects.

siblings:cell death.name: Entosis
siblings:cell death.description: A non-apoptotic cell death process in which one live cell is engulfed by another and subsequently degraded within a lysosome-rich vacuole.

siblings:cell death.name: Methuosis
siblings:cell death.description: A non-apoptotic form of cell death characterized by the massive accumulation of fluid-filled vacuoles derived from macropinosomes.

siblings:cell death.name: Cornification
siblings:cell death.description: A specialized form of terminal differentiation and cell death occurring in the epidermis, resulting in the formation of the stratum corneum.

siblings:cell death.name: Oncosis
siblings:cell death.description: A pre-lethal pathway leading to cell death characterized by cellular and organelle swelling, often associated with ischemic injury.
